details.title: Joint Failure Importance for Noncoherent Fault Trees

authors.affiliation: Univ. of Ontario Inst. of Technol., Oshawa

p: Lixuan Lu received her BEsc., and MEsc. in 1998, and 2001, respectively, from Beijing Institute of Technology in China; and her Ph.D in 2005 from the University of Western Ontario, Canada. She is currently an assistant professor at the School of Energy Systems and Nuclear Science, and Faculty of Engineering and Applied Science at the University of Ontario Institute of Technology, Canada. Her research interests include Probabilistic Safety Assessment, Maintenance, and Instrumentation and Control Systems in Nuclear Power Plants.

authors.name: Lixuan Lu

p: Jin Jiang received his BESc. in 1982 from Xi'an Jiaotong University in China; and MESc., and Ph.D. in 1984, and 1989, respectively, from the University of New Brunswick in Canada. He joined the University of Western Ontario in 1991 where he is a Professor in the Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering. He is currently an NSERC/UNENE Senior Industrial Research Chair in Instrumentation, Control, and Electrical Systems for Nuclear Power Plants. His research interests are in the area of fault-tolerant control system design and analysis, power system dynamics and control, and signal processing for diagnosis.

details.abstract: There exist several risk importance measures in the literature to rank the relative importance among basic events within a fault tree. Most of the importance measures indicate how important a basic event is with respect to the top event of the fault tree. However, the mutual influence among the basic events should also be considered. This is particularly true in practice when making maintenance decisions with a limited resource. This paper investigates the Joint Failure Importance (JFI), which reflects the interaction among basic events, namely, the change in the Birnbaum Importance of one basic event when the probability of another basic event changes. Even though the JFI for coherent fault trees and its properties have been examined in the literature, the results cannot be easily extended to noncoherent fault trees. The current work has shown that, for both coherent, and noncoherent fault trees, the sign of the JFI can provide useful information. However, the properties of the JFI for noncoherent fault trees are more complex, and do not always share with those for coherent fault trees. The Shutdown System Number One (SDS1) in a Canadian Deuterium-Uranium (CANDU) Nuclear Power Plant (NPP) is utilized to illustrate the theoretical results developed in this paper.

references.title: Importance analysis with Markov chains

context.text: There are several importance measures available in the literature, both in the field of Reliability Engineering [2], [3], and Probabilistic Safety Assessment (PSA) [4], [5].

links.abstract: In this paper, the authors introduce novel techniques for computing importance measures in state space dependability models. Specifically, reward functions in a Markov reward model (MRM) are utilized for this purpose, in contrast to the common method of computing importance measures through combinatorial models and structure functions. The advantage of bringing these measures in the context of MRMs is that the mapping extends the applicability of these substantial results of reliability engineer...

references.text: R. M. Fricks, K. S. Trivedi, "Importance analysis with Markov chains", Annual Proceedings of the Reliability and Maintenance Symposium, pp. 89-95, 2003.

links.abstract: Various results concerning importance measures and rankings of system components are presented. The vectors (of component states) which appear useful in studying various component importance measures are decomposed. In particular, a new method to compute Birnbaum importance measures of components is introduced. For some systems and components the Vesely-Fussell importance measure might not be suitable; thus a new importance measure is proposed. By using the notion of component criticality introd...

references.text: F. C. Meng, "Comparing the importance of system components by some structural characteristics", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 45, no. 1, pp. 59-65, Mar. 1996.

references.title: Joint reliability-importance of components

context.text: However, it can also provide useful insights on how two basic events interact with each other when the probability of one event changes [7].

links.abstract: Hong & Lie (1993) defined joint reliability importance (JRI) as a measure of how two components in a system interact in contributing to system reliability. Their definition and theorems regarding JRI were limited to statistically independent component states. This paper removes the statistical independence restriction by showing that similar results hold in the more general case where component failures can be statistically dependent; however, the calculation of actual values becomes more diffic...

references.text: M. J. Armstrong, "Joint reliability-importance of components", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 44, no. 3, pp. 408-412, Sept. 1995.

references.title: Reactor Safety StudyAn Assessment of Accident Risks in US Nuclear Power Plants,

context.text: The method of fault trees is one of the widely used techniques for risk & reliability assessment. “Fault tree analysis can be defined to be a systematic procedure used to identify & record the various combinations of component fault states (modes), and other basic events that can result in a predefined undesired state of a system” [8].

references.text: Reactor Safety StudyAn Assessment of Accident Risks in US Nuclear Power Plants, 1975.

references.title: Computer-aided synthesis of fault trees

context.text: An early work on noncoherent fault trees can be traced back to 1977 [11].

links.abstract: An algorithm is presented for the synthesis of fault-trees. The fault-tree is deduced directly from a digraph (directed graph) model of the system being analyzed. The digraph describes the normal, failed, and conditional relationships which exist between variables and events in the system. A computer program which uses this algorithm is illustrated for a chemical processing system.

references.text: S. A. Lapp, G. J. Powers, "Computer-aided synthesis of fault trees", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-26, pp. 2-11, Apr. 1977.

links.abstract: The Lapp & Powers (L&P) fault-tree model of a nitric acid cooling process is explored to a greater level of depth than in the previous round-robin correspondence on the controversy over exclusive-or (XOR) gate G7 in the L&P fault tree. In this paper, the minimalized logic equations for success or failure of G7 are derived, and the subsystem reliability function is calculated. The subsystem reliability vs component reliability function is U-shaped; this is not an abnormality, but a result of the ...

links.abstract: This paper extends methods for evaluating the s-importance of elements and cut-sets of s-coherent systems to elements and prime implicants of non-coherent systems. Existing measures of s-importance are redefined to provide general expressions for the system elements and prime implicants when non-coherent systems are encountered. The redefined measures utilize the methodology of I&H and the absolute value of the influence of event i (or prime implicant j) on the top-event occurrence probability (...

references.text: P. S. Jackson, "On the S-importance of elements and prime implicants of noncoherent systems", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-32, no. 1, pp. 21-25, Apr. 1983.

references.title:
Birnbaum's measure of component importance
for noncoherent systems

context.text: The most recent study of noncoherent fault trees can be found in [14], and [15], where several importance measures have been introduced.
The BI for noncoherent fault trees generally consists of two parts: the Birnbaum failure-critical importance, and the Birnbaum repair-critical importance [14].

It has been shown in [14] that the Birnbaum importance of the basic event \$i\$ in a noncoherent fault tree is the combination of the Birnbaum failure-critical importance, and the Birnbaum repair-critical importance, as in The reason for having both \$BI_{i}^{\rm F}(\vec{q},\vec{p})\$, and \$BI_{i}^{\rm R}(\vec{q},\vec{p})\$ is because not only the occurrence of a basic event, but also the nonoccurrence of a basic event can result in the occurrence of the top event in a noncoherent fault tree.

links.abstract: Importance analysis of noncoherent systems is limited, and is generally inaccurate because all measures of importance that have been developed are strictly for coherent analysis. This paper considers the probabilistic measure of component importance developed by Birnbaum (1969). An extension of this measure is proposed which enables noncoherent importance analysis. As a result of the proposed extension the average number of system failures in a given interval for noncoherent systems can be calcu...

references.text: J. D. Andrews, S. Beeson, "Birnbaum's measure of component importance for noncoherent systems", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 52, no. 2, pp. 213-219, June 2003.

references.title:
Importance measures for noncoherent-system
analysis

context.text: The most recent study of noncoherent fault trees can be found in [14], and [15], where several importance measures have been introduced.

links.abstract: Component importance analysis is a key part of the system reliability quantification process. It enables the weakest areas of a system to be identified and indicates modifications, which will improve the system reliability. Although a wide range of importance measures have been developed, the majority of these measures are strictly for coherent system analysis. Noncoherent systems can occur and accurate importance analysis is essential. This paper extends four commonly used measures of importanc...

references.text: S. Beeson, J. D. Andrews, "Importance measures for noncoherent-system analysis", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 52, no. 3, pp. 301-310, Sept. 2003.

references.title:
Joint reliability-importance of two edges in an undirected
network

context.text: Furthermore, Joint Failure Importance was originally defined in [16] for two edges in an undirected network.
The JFI between the basic events \$i\$ and \$j\$ in a coherent fault tree is defined as [16] It has been shown therein that the following properties of JFI exist for coherent fault trees.

Although the results in [16] are not presented in the exact format as below, the structure is similar.

1)
Property III-A.1 Property III-A.1 can be used to calculate the JFI between the basic events \$i\$ and \$j\$ by computing the probability of the top event under different conditions. for example, \$Q(\vec{q}\vert q_{i}=1,q_{j}=1)\$ is the probability of the top event when both the basic events \$i\$ and \$j\$ have occurred. \$Q(\vec{q}\vert q_{i}=0,q_{j}=1)\$ is the probability of the top event when the basic event \$i\$ did not occur, but the basic event \$j\$ has occurred. \$Q(\vec{q}\vert q_{i}=1,q_{j}=0)\$, and \$Q(\vec{q}\vert q_{i}=0,q_{j}=0)\$ can be interpreted similarly.

2)
Property III-A.2Equation (7) indicates the relationship between the JFI, and the BI.

links.abstract: Joint reliability importance (JRI) of two edges in an undirected network is introduced. Concepts of joint failure importance (JFI) and marginal failure importance (MFI), duals of JRI and marginal reliability importance (MRI), are also introduced. The JRI of two edges in an undirected network is represented by the MRI of each edge in subnetworks. Relationships between JRI and MRI, JRI and JFI, and JFI and MFI are presented. From these relationships, it is shown that the JRI is an appropriate quan...

references.text: S. Hong, C. H. Lie, "Joint reliability-importance of two edges in an undirected network", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 42, no. 1, pp. 17-33, Mar. 1993.
